title: Using Create Bulk Connections fails when attempting to add password to container.
author: cuhlrich-ttm
body_snippet:
## Expected Behavior
After `Get-Credential` is called as shown in the example, the containers should have the username and password supplied within them.
 
## Current Behavior
If a password is supplied in the pop up prompt, the generation of the xml file will fail.

## Possible Solution
Not sure, I tinkered with this for several hours and couldn't come up with a good solution.

## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)
1. Copy the `CreateBulkConnections_ConfCons2_6.ps1` from [here](https://gith...

iterations.description: When importing CSV connections, the password for containers is incorrectly assigned to the inherited ConnectionInfo.Password property instead of the ContainerInfo.ContainerPassword property, preventing proper folder protection.

comments.author: robertpopa22
comments.snippet: Triage refresh (P2): this issue has been inactive for a long time. Please retest on the latest build and share reproducible steps, expected vs actual behavior, and logs/screenshots. If there is no confirmation/update, maintainers can close it as stale or not reproducible.

notes:
AI triage (gemini): When importing CSV connections, the password for containers is incorrectly assigned to the inherited ConnectionInfo.Password property instead of the ContainerInfo.ContainerPassword property, preventing proper folder protection.
Approach: Modify CsvConnectionsDeserializerMremotengFormat.cs to distinguish between ConnectionInfo and ContainerInfo when assigning the password during CSV import. If the record is a ContainerInfo, assign the password to ContainerPassword. Also, ensure the Password property in AbstractConnectionRecord is correctly typed as string, as seen in the analysis.
